segments.text: What's wrong with that?
There it goes.
Okay, so you were part of the occupation forces.
That's right.
Anyhow, you know we acquired the Virgin Islands from Denmark, $13 million, the three islands, St. John, St. Thomas, and St. Croix.
And we were stationed in the old gendarme barracks there.
As I said, I commanded the 21st Company in St. Croix.
I was post-treasurer, acting assistant quartermaster, and I was also the judge advocate.
I didn't get that down there.
Okay.
How many men did you have under your command then when you left as a captain?
A Marine company in those days was 100 men.
In this occupation force, it was the 21st Company and the 149th Company and a...
a detachment of artillery and a detachment of signal and all that was assigned over there on our island.
How'd you get along with the people in the Virgin Islands?
Uh, good and bad.
I guess, uh, of course I was a Marine.
I didn't fraternize with the natives and uh,
I just tended my own business, and I had a lot to tend to, because as you can notice, they loaded me up with assignments.
You had a lot of jobs.
How'd you do all of these things?
Well, they said they wanted to docinate me well in the Marine Corps and give me a chance for the experience.
All right.
I returned to the States, and I...
I, uh...
resigned to be the captain in 1920.
But I remembered well what General Pershing had to say, that if they'd have left a million men in Germany, they'd never have another world war.
But they didn't do that.
So immediately shortly thereafter, I became re-affiliated with Marine Corps and was appointed a captain of the Marine Corps reserve.
And I served, as I say, in many assignments, active duty for training each year, attended schools, Jackson, Barrack, New Orleans, where we studied the draft act and promoted to major.
I didn't go in detail all these different assignments,
Could you describe the reserve organization during the inter-year wars?
Could you describe what it was like to be a reserve in 1920?
Oh, there was no such thing.
I wasn't a reserve officer in World War I. I was a regular officer.
I know that, but after you left... Yeah.
First, could you tell me, did you ever think about staying in the Marines as a profession, as a career in 1920?
Yes, I did.
Why didn't you?
The reason I wanted to stay was I had a brother back here who was bugging me to get out because he said he wanted me to go in business with him.
He had had some oil leases up in McCullough County and was in show business and had a well, an outfit to clean oil wells and so forth and so on.
I didn't want to get out of the Marine Corps at all, period.
But anyhow.
You enjoyed being a Marine.
I enjoyed being a Marine.
I didn't want to get out of the Marine Corps at all, but he reminded me that he helped me through college and so forth, and I owed him something, which I felt I didn't.
However, I regret that I didn't turn my back on and could have stayed in the Marine Corps and didn't.
But however, I became affiliated, and I don't regret that.
It created a lot of inconvenience, but I didn't care anything about that either.
Okay, so in 1920, you came back to Houston then?
Came back to Houston.
Okay.
I built the building out in Fifth Ward for my brother, a theater.
A theater.
Which one?
Well, it's called the Roxson Theater.
That was way back down there.
But it was in the neighborhood where they had whites and blacks and everything like that, and I hated show business.
I didn't want anything like that because I had worked for the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and I served in the ring corps with honor.
and all like that, and I didn't like the show business, didn't like it at all.
You didn't like the people in show business, or what didn't you like about it?
I didn't want show business.
I wanted something else.
Yeah, I was trained in agriculture.
I had dreams of being an agriculturist on a large scale.
Yeah.
And all of that, but there I was.
But anyhow, I went on that on, and then a little bit later on, I got in the knack of business with him and accumulated a little property.
What kind of agribusiness?
What kind of what?
What kind of business?
Real estate.
Oh, real estate business.
That's right.
In Houston here.
Acquiring real estate, rental property and things like that.
Later on...
This is during the 1920s then.
2030s up in there.
I was licensed as a lawyer in 32.
Okay, well, tell me about why did you decide to go to law.
Did you go to law school or did you study law?
Tell me about how did you become a lawyer?
Well, in the Marine Corps, every officer was a law officer.
Every officer could be a judge advocate.
Every officer could be a incidental.
That's one of the things we learned in Marine Corps schools.
You could be a recorder on a summary court.
You could run a summary court.
You could be a prosecutor.
We've taught all that.
Every Marine officer's loss and every Marine officer aboard a battleship was the judge advocate who ran all the courts aboard ship.
So they taught it back in the school.
Becoming a lawyer was a matter that I had become involved with my brother and he was
We'd acquired something and it was questioned.
Anyhow, about that time I had put my wife in dental school.
When did you get married?
I got married twice.
I got a child by prior marriage.
One daughter, she's got five daughters, lived down in Louisiana.
But I've been married to this woman since 1927, I think it is.
Anyhow,

So I went to the South Texas School of Law down in YMCA and I realized that being over that couple of months that I'd had a lot of experience in business, I'd had a lot of experience in court work in the Marine Corps, and I decided I didn't have any time to waste sitting around listening to people
reciting class.
So I went to the Houston Law School where they threw the course at you in three years, summer and winter, and then you took the bar examination and you took it from there.
So you passed the bar in 1932.
It is, okay.
But being a lawyer in the Marine Corps helped me quite a bit, too.
How?
It enhanced, because they figured lawyers could make decisions.
They figured lawyers could reason things out.
They figured lawyers could do a lot of things.
And a lot of our commanding generals were lawyers.
My General Vogel was a lawyer, a graduate of George Washington.
And General Price was a lawyer.
All of them, but they had had that training.
So as I say, when I...
So I said, I said many a time that I could do the training, and he tended to say, all right.
Now, let's get back... That's when, that's where I realized...
as I do today, the importance of bringing the draft back immediately.
Because that's where you get a cross-section of everybody.
And before long, Reagan is going to have to give up because... Give up what?
What do you mean?
Give up on the draft.
Have to give up on it.
I believe in the draft.
I believe we have to have a cross-section of all people.
You understand?
You just can't have...
So in other words, you support the draft.
I support the draft more so after I went and took this course in Jackson Barracks.
Okay, okay.
Tell me about that course.
Well, the course was...
You know, the draft act was set up in World War I by the Honorable Andrew Johnson, who was head of the National Recovery Act.
And we had five of his administrators there teaching us how to administer the act, what to look for, how to pick out homosexuals, and all of those kind of things.
And how to administer the act when time came and all like that.
And the executive officer of that school, believe it or not, was Major Hussey.
He had been shot in one eye in France, who later became head of the draft until he died.
I was always wanting to know what he thought about me.
He gave me a good fitness report.
We attended this with five regular marine officers and five reserve officers.
General Hershey did?
No, no, no, no.
Marines going to this school at Jackson Barracks.
National Guard, Army, Navy, Coast Guard, everything.
Everybody was going, okay.
Right.
Okay.
And he told me, and I didn't know he was going to put it in my record at the time I...
of an emergency in time of war that I'd be better off in the field with commanding men than I would be trying to administer this act in some state capital.
I thought it was quite an honor.
Sure.
But I didn't want that, but anyhow, I had the knowledge about the draft.
Okay, good.
Where were we now?
No, I wanted to, when did you join, when did you get involved with the reserves?
When I was recommissioned.
Okay, when were you recommissioned?
In 1920, you resigned, and then when did you get back in as a Marine Corps Reserve?
See what that commission is right there.
Okay, 1927.
So you got out of the service in 1920, and then you went back in 1927.
Yeah, but that commission dated on.
It really was 1926.
That's how I don't match the material.
Okay, 1926.
But it all during that time that I was around Marines here in Houston.
Mm-hmm.
And we had a camaraderie...
Well, we met all ex-Marines.
We had the McLemore Detachment of the Marine Corps League.
There's a medal sitting over yonder if you want to take a look at it.
There, right there.
There, down there.
So I really never ceased being a Marine.
Right.
And what was it like?
Did you get paid being in the Marines when you went back in in 1926, 27?
Yes, every time I went on active duty I got paid.
And did you go on active duty on the weekends?
No, no, no, no, no.
Those days there was no organized reserve.
Okay, tell me about that.
The only time we got paid is when we went on active duty for training.
So we went to Quantico, Virginia, and a lot of times I'd join a battalion that's going to be...
What were we talking about?
Well, we were talking about what it was like to be in the Marine Corps Reserves.
And you were talking about if they paid you, or we were talking about paying and going on.
Did you go for, like, two-week summer camps?
Yeah.
Okay, and that's when the Marines paid you.
But otherwise, when you just met, they didn't pay.
Is that correct?
No.
Okay, and how often did you meet?
You mean the...
Did I take that down?
What did I do?
I have this right here.
Where's my copy?
Here, use that one.
Oh, no, no, no, hell no.
Goddamn, I'm nuts, you know.
Yeah.
Oh, okay, there it is.
I had put in to have a reserve company in Houston, a reserve battalion.
But I wasn't strong politically, and they gave it to the Honorable Clark Thompson down in Galveston, who was kin to the Moody's and all like that, so he had the 15th Battalion.
Okay, so you didn't get the battalion, or you didn't get the reserve unit yourself?
No, I did not.
I went to Galveston and called the 15th Battalion.
Okay.
Under Clark Thompson, who was the son-in-law of the Moody's, and had been an ex-Congressman, or was going to be a Congressman.
So were you in his unit?
No, I was never in his unit, only for training in the summertime.
We went to Palacios, we went to, where the hell was that place, Beauregard in Louisiana, and we went to, oh,
various other places where they would meet.
One time we went as far as Quantico, Virginia.
Really?
Yeah.
Anyhow, but as I say, I went on and did my training and did what I was supposed to do.
And I was promoted to major after taking the professional examination in 1940.
And the funny thing about that, I received a letter from an Aggie by the name of
Walker later on got to be a lieutenant general, and I used to haze him in B Company at A&M College.
Oh, really?
And he wrote me a letter and said, you are qualified physically, educationally, morally, but not professionally.
And unless you complete certain work within a certain time, we will have to retire you from the Marine Corps Reserve.
So I wrote to Marine Corps school and found out what I had to do and what they wanted.

And I went down to Gauss to a friend of mine who was inspecting instructors, Lieutenant Colonel down there, Marines who had served with him in the tropics, Colonel Holmes, and he schooled me about three months.
And then he announced me ready and I went down and took the professional examination and I was made a major shortly thereafter.
But the only thing, I was glad I took the course because it made me professionally fit.
And they gave me all the courses, they gave me the works, and I took it.

Later on I found out other people had been made major without taking the examination, but also in my own mind felt that I was better off than they were because I was qualified enough for what I was doing than they were not.
And what did these courses deal with?
What type of topics?
Small wars, the machine gun and defense, the machine gun and attack, the oceanography, ship to shore movements, techniques and tactics, artillery and defense, and logistics, and...

writing orders for an attack, and carrying a campaign from its inception, the intelligence part of it, and this, that, and the other, until you brought it right to the combination where either one of you lost supplies and all that, transportation.
And as I say, it gives a full course on small wars, which we fought in the tropics in Haiti and San Domingo and Nicaragua.
There's another thing I was interested in, and that was, were you building a law practice in Houston while you were being a reserve officer then?
Well, we stopped there, and as I say, I opened a law office in the Shell building.
and had my other real estate and theater interests, too.
And I was associated with T.J. We represented mortgage loan bank at T.J. Bettison.
Incidentally, I became associated with an Aggie by the name of Frank R. Gwynn, whose father came up there at Russ, Texas.
And he was a fifth generation lawyer, and he's a fine lawyer.
That was mostly my practice, mortgage loan, probate work, and little corporation work, and very little criminal work.
Now, you were promoted to major in June of 1940.
Can you tell me what happened then?
All right.
Soon after that, just prior to this appointment,
I had been out in San Diego with the 15th Battalion, and when I arrived home, I had orders on my desk asking me to organize a Marine Battalion in Houston.
Bet you were happy about that.

Yes, well I tried, and I had got two companies together, and they made us come on to active duty, and they joined and merged into 2nd Battalion, 8th Marines, I got a whole lot of damn pictures on that in there, of the troops.
I said, you could just go on, hell, how damn it be that much.
Nobody wants to read that much.
You want to be brief, concise, just like the book I had, which I loaned a fellow, the generals after Appomattox.
It went along there, it said about Lawrence Sullivan Ross and all that.
He did so many things, but hell, he got it all condensed down.
I understand all that.
I said, we could just look, pile it that high.
Okay.
Now, what did you do in the Battalion 8th Marines?
Tell me about that.
What were your functions and duties there?

In the 2nd Battalion 8th Marines, my outfit just went to the 2nd Battalion 8th Marines, and immediately, as a major, they had no room for me, so I went up to the regimental staff as a law officer and personnel and so forth and so on.
See?
Sure.
Additional duty as a member of the general court martial down in the Navy District.
So you took care of the legal work then?
Sure, I drew up wills, but I was in personnel.
Right.
Sure.
See?
I was in personnel.
All right.
That was in the 8th Marines.
And then later on, the 8th Marines shut off.
I transferred all my activities to the 2nd Marine Division, which I didn't put in here.
Mm-hmm.
See, then I went to the Corps, the Corps staff when I'm back, and that's where I was when they took me away from that staff to send me to Samoa because I'll tell you why.
Okay.
But when did you go active duty?
When did you change from a reserve?
December, when they called us in December 1940.
Okay, December 1940, you went active duty.
Were you happy to be back on active duty?
Of course, I left my business and everything else, but that didn't make any difference to me.
I was happy.
I just turned my stuff over to other people and whatever they did with it, they put the money in their pocket, whatever they did, that was that.
That didn't make any difference.
Because the reason I always was affiliated, because I always knew that what Pershing said was true.
They would have another war unless we leave a million men in Germany.
The truth would be right.
All right.
So you thought you'd be going back, and you thought the United States would be certainly going back?
Sure.
Okay, into the war.
You had Hitler, and you had all that stuff.
And I will say one thing about, I belonged to the America's Club here in Houston, which was a bunch of Italian, people of Italian parentage, professionals.
And they were always bragging about Mussolini.
But one day I got up and made a speech that was very unpopular
I said that the Romans gave us our laws and out of those laws we bolded a constitution and we developed one of the greatest countries in the world, the United States of America.
Yet where this law emanated, back in Italy, they had to resort to dictatorship which would fall, which would fall.
That same year I went to
St. Louis on a Marine, American Legion convention.
I went with a fellow named Chido who was going to be decorated by the Italian government and went up to the Italian council up in some building in St. Louis.
And he had a picture of Mussolini and it was blowing out from the wall.
And this guy said, oh, look how great a man he is.
And I said, he's just full of wind.
That wind is blowing him away from the wall.
The fellow I was with
who's going to get this decorated, stepped on my foot.
He says, can't you be a gentleman?
I said, I'm only telling the truth, and I knew what was going to happen, and it did happen.
All right.
So when you went in December 1940, you were active duty again, and tell me what you did.
You went to San Diego then?
That's right.
Okay.
I went to San Diego, and that's where the headquarters of the
The 1st and 8th Marines Regiment, and then the 2nd Marine Division, then the One-Eyed Mac.
And what is the One-Eyed Mac?
What does that mean?
That meant the outfit that was going to run Guadalcanal Show.
Oh, okay.
That was the code of it.
Okay.
But I was taken away from that staff and sent to... Samoa.
Samoa.
and joined the brigade down there in American Samoa.
Was that 1942?
Yeah.
That was the idea was to support the Tarawa operation.
That was the idea of reactivating those islands there, American Samoa, Western Samoa, and the Wallace Island, which is the French Samoa.
And I was the first and only Marine officer in American Samoa to support Tarawa operation.
What did you do there at Samoa?
Wait a minute.
When I arrived there, I went out to brigade to see my friend, my commanding general, who I'd served with in the Marines, and another friend of mine, Raymond Knapp.
And I asked him, why did you all take me away from General Vogel?
And he said, well, the attorney general has been held on this island for many years by our Navy people.
And they're so soft, they have never talked to me.
the people how to work on these islands.
And we were looking for a lawyer, we were looking for a southerner, we were looking for an administrator, we were looking for a marine.
Because the guy who's coming here, although he is a marine, he's a graduate of the Naval Academy, and we don't think much of him.
So he tapped me.
So the commanding... Why do you want a southerner?
Why do you say, I want a southerner?
That's what they said.
Because a lot of them people were black, too.
Anyhow, that's what they said.
I don't mean to, you know, I don't want to stuff anything.
You can delete that if you want.
I don't care.
So, I was the first and only Marine officer serving the 10th General and Pro-War Marshals and the Military Governor of Samoan and the Samoan Defense Brigade.
See reports on tenure of Officer of the Water and Navy Accommodation Medal
with ribbon for said service.
OK, General Nunn.
Tell me what you did in Samoa.
I'm OK right now.
OK, good.
I want to know what you did in Samoa.
Okay, that's your Samoa file.
Okay.
There's some material there to start a book with.
Anyhow, the idea was my commanding general told me that they wanted, as the attorney general for Oklahoma Marshal, I was executive officer of the naval government.
Executive officer.
I signed my name to 22 different titles.
No kidding?
All right, I was the lawyer, the high lawyer, attorney general, who was executive officer of the government.
The Provo March was a Samoan area, all in combined, but all they gave it to me, they said, you got the law west of the Pecos, take it all.
I was a V.C.
officer for the State Department.
I'd get permits to the Line Islands for a sewer.
I was officer of the Navy Bank in Samoa.
I was head of the Labor Board.
I was head of the, I was on the Custom Board.
I was warden of the Naval Prisons.
I was warden of the native prison.
I was head of tax collecting.
I was head of tax assessment.
I was head of the Department of Agriculture.
I was head of the Department of Native Industries, like that thing you see over there on the wall, that club thing like that.
I was head of the Department of Native...
I was legal representative of the island government.
I was a prosecutor in the criminal court.
I had power adoption.
I was a trustee for the Mormon Ranch.
I was area assignment security officer.
I was head of the liquor control board.
I was a brand major, which means a fire marshal.
And I was on the hospital board.
You did all of that?
I did that.
I had 22 different battles.
Did you ever have time to sleep?
Damn little.
Damn little.
All right, for my service, I don't mind being braggadocious about it, but there is my, there are my annual reports for my two years, practically two years of tenure of office.
There they are right there.
Where we go into a whole lot of stuff.
The Native industry.
Tell me how you got along with the Samoan people.
I got along with Samoan people because I was firm and I was fair.
When I set up the labor board, I meant no partiality.
I had power to appoint the governors from the four districts.
And these four districts came from Samoan.
And we operated through the chief.
And I well remember the first speech I made.
My commanding general told me to go down there and look at the laws.
They were in existence, change any of them by direction to suit the job, get on with the war so that the natives could cooperate, so our Marines could go on in training instead of unloading ships.
And so the Navy was sitting down there expecting to build a Navy base, which never happened, and they never unloaded any ships.
So the idea was to get us there,
get the natives to do the work, work unloading ships, work on the roads, and do things so that Marines and other people could be released and get on with the training.
Didn't they do the work?
All this stuff, these are the annual reports.
Did the Samoans do the work?
The Samoans did their work.
They never had anybody's bad eye on them because the Navy had what they called a feeder-feeder guard there.
And through that feeder-feeder guard, which was formed in 1904,
They lived, the whole island.
They didn't have to work.
They just sat down and fished and grow taro and this, that, and the other.
They didn't have to do any work.
They didn't have to work.
The sea was full of fish.
So how'd you get them to take over these new duties now?
I'm sure I'll tell you in a minute.
So on my way back from brigade headquarters, I stopped at my military police headquarters to announce them that I was their new provost marshal.
I was at Utilee, so I had an office down there, too.
Feet of field guard, you can have that.
Those are the people whose salaries filtered through every native community and family on the island.
Feeder, feeder, put it on back there.
Feeder, feeder, go.
F-I-T-E, F-I-T-E. All right.
Here, you can have this.
How'd you get the people to take over work?
So when I reported, I was immediately assigned a jeep.
The Attorney General had a station wagon.
I said, I didn't want that.
I went down to this office of the Attorney General.
And the first person I saw was a barefooted Samoan with a shark lay around his neck, barefooted and a lava lava.
So I said to him, what's your job?
He says, I'm your chief of police.
My name is Paley.
Paley means strong in Samoan.
So I said to him, I am the attorney general.
I'm your lawyer, Celia Celia, and I'm the provost of Marquis Island.
And I understand by reading that we have chiefs in the different districts.
And I want those chiefs to have as many people of their villages in this courtroom tomorrow morning.
So as Bush telegraphed word from one to the other,
The next morning, the courtroom was filled up, and I got up and made them a speech.
And I told them I didn't ask for this duty.
But the war was on, and we had to reorganize and disrupt their easy life where they could sleep all day and fish when they wanted to and grow breadfruit.
And now the women do all the washing, and they said we had to go to work.
We had to protect this country.
If they want to do a part,
in this Japanese war so they could win it.
They'd have to change their lives, which I apologize very much for disrupting it.
And we have to change things.
Everybody's gonna work on this island.
Everybody's gonna produce.
We're gonna set up a labor board.
Those who are physically qualified are gonna have to work on the roads
You're going to have to keep up your own plantation.
You're going to have to cut off the food supply.
We cannot be bringing food down from the United States for you people when you can grow it here yourself.
We're going to cut off a lot of other supplies, shoes and things and other that you get out of San Francisco.
We're going to have to cut that off the, you know what I'm talking about, the list.
And we're going to bring down warm material.
We're going to bring down concrete.
We're going to bring down materials, cement,
and other materials to win the war with.
And you're going to have to learn to live what you've got.
And I'm going to only let necessities come to this island.
What'd they say?
They didn't say anything.
I told them that was it.
So I got through talking to them.
The next morning, we had all the natives that could be physically able to work, all the men, report for physical examination.
And the next morning, they went to work.
We had trucks go out into the areas and pick them up.
And we taught them how to unload ship.
We taught them how to be a winchman.
We taught them how to do this, how to drop the slings in the hole and all like that.
I cooperated with the supply officer, who was a Navy man.
I also issued an order immediately that instead of having one sling down in the hole and unload the ship, we're going to have four slings.
And as the law officer of the island aboard ship, they had four rules.
No stealing, no sleeping, no, let's see, sleeping, stealing, drinking, and I had one else.
So we set to work, and first thing you know, these people went to work seriously about it.
And we used the feet of feet of guards as guards on these ships.
Everybody that came on there had to have a ticket.
No sleeping, no smoking, no stealing.
It was another asshole.
I forget what it was.
But anyhow, at any time anybody violated that, the feet of feet of guards brought him in, and I would prosecute him.
And rather than put him in jail, I'd fine him.
And I built up $300,000 or $30,000 in the hospital fund on those fines.
Anyhow, I could hold court any time.
The court consisted of one naval lieutenant commander and three native judges.
We had no jury, so I'd write out the complaint.
They'd come in and give me the complaint.
I'd write it out.
If there was any merit to it, I'd go on and prosecute.
If it wasn't, I'd give them a warning and go on about their business.
As I say, I gave you all the duties.
I had the power of adoption.
And I found out then that those natives had more sense than we do because they'd bring in a family who had eight children.
They wouldn't adopt just one child.
They'd adopt every other child so the kids could be raised together.
Those were natives.
Anyhow, my citation there, I won't.

I did a job there, and I was the last, first and last Marine officer to ever hold that job because the military, the government, after I left there, went from the military government to the Samoan Defense Area back to the Navy, and from the Navy it went to the Department of the Interior, which is down there now.
How'd you like that duty?
I didn't like the duty.
Why not?
Because it was too...
I had...
I had every ship that came in there.
I forgot that.
Every ship that came in there, the skipper had to report to me.

And if he was having any difficulties with the crew, I had power from Admiral Hawes to take him off and try him or send him back on his own transportation back to the United States and take him off the ship.
That was some of my jobs.
I had a lot of jobs to do.
Did you ever have to do that with any captain?
I did that with two or three people.
I got a file of letters where lawyers wrote me after I went on inactive duty trying to straight them up and get their money back, but that didn't mean anything to me.
I catch them stealing or selling whiskey on the beach, anything like that, and they brought them in.
The skipper would come with the complaint and bring the defendant there, and then I'd take him from there.
That was it.
But I...
It was a hell of a job.
Another thing.
Wait a minute.
One of the things I had, I had a leper calling.
I forgot that.
Oh, you really?
Give me a... Where's that damn thing?
I forgot.
Right here.
That right there?
No, I don't want that.
You want a pen?
Leper calling up on the side of the mountain.
And I also ran the nut house.
Crazy house.
I had a feeder running that.
One day he let a damn crazy guy get in there and drown.
And he come telling me, I said, I just warned you last week.
The ship was very well out of the water, and his name was Pai Tata.
And he hit one of them natives who had a fake sardine can for a number.
And he hit him and knocked him all down the ladder, and he hit the other guy.
Every step on them buses, they had wide open.
I had to relieve him of that, so I sent him over to the nut house, and next week he come over, he done drowned one of those poor crazy people.
Oh, Christ.
Well, who was your commanding general then?
Was there a general in charge?
There he is right there, General Henry L. Lawson.
Lawson?
That's right.
Okay.
He married.
And so you were his assistant, more or less.
No, this was back in his assistant.
I was his provost and lieutenant general.
He was the military governor.
Okay, he was the military governor.
This was back in Guam where I got the Legion of Merit.
Okay.
The...
My duties in Samoa are covered by this citation.

Meritorious conduct in the performance of outstanding service to the government of the United States as Attorney General and Provo Marshal of the Military Government of America of Samoa from July 29, 1942 to the 18th of November, 1943.
During this critical period, he was charged with the maintaining law and order

among military and civilian personnel, prosecuting all actions before the court for the island government, indoctrinating natives with the principles of war or effort, and numerous additional duties of importance.
His astute diplomacy and extraordinary administrative and professional abilities aided materially in fostering a real consciousness of obligation by the civilians as well as the military
military personnel to the United States government in time of war.
His conduct was all the time in keeping with the highest tradition of naval service.
That tells you what my job, what I did.
But a lot of people don't know about all this other stuff.
Well, of course, there's instances I could go on and elaborate and so forth and so on, you know what I mean?
Now... Did you think that Europe, that you did, that, uh,
The most difficult chore was to getting the Samoan people to get used to the war effort and all those changes?
They were not.
They were for a little while there, but I had very little resistance because they knew I was fair and I was stern.
Yeah.
Now, a lot of times there's some Marine officer who comes right in the seat for some native that I had in the jail.
Mm-hmm.
So, uh,
I'd look at him, I says, do I ever come over to your 50 caliber group and tell you how to run your battery?
He said, no, sir.
I said, why don't you come over here?
I said, you're doing push-push with the man's sister, you're right.
He said, yes, sir.
I said, well, you better get on over there before I lock you up.
So I put him under arrest as Provo Marshal.
I had the military law, I had the civil law, I had it all.
And General Lawson gave me that.
Later on after General Lawson left, I was under the Samoan
Defense Command.
And after that, of course, I was relieved and came on back to the States.
Oh, tell me about that.
All right.
Returned to the United States.
Why were you relieved of that duty?
Because my time was up.
I'd given them everything.
Okay.
And I didn't want to stay there after my commanding general left, who caught me there.
Okay.
Okay, fine.
I didn't have any.
They knew.
They knew what to do.
Okay.
See, so they went back to the old ways.
Okay.
Nonchalant.
I well remember one time.
So the Samoans went to the old ways then?
They went different ways.
They bettered themselves, but they were not under the pressure of war.
Okay, fine.
I well remember down there in Samoa that the airplane tender came in there to take certain personnel from the 2nd Defense Battalion away, and I was down on the dock.
And the skipper of the ship was ready to shove off.
And he was wanting a pilot to take him out.
So he hollered down at me and said, who runs this place?
I said, no, I don't.
Well, he says, well, this pilot's going to take me out.
I said, well, I think they're out there.
He said, yeah, but I think they're coming back with a couple of tuna boats.
So he yelled from the bridge, says, you people must think I'm sitting on an Evinrude motor hill.
I'm going to shove off here myself without a pilot.
And with that, he did.
That's right.
Anyhow, so much for Samoa.
And I returned to the United States.
And I was legal officer of the Fleet and Marine Forces San Diego area.
And I was a G2, I wanted to put two and I got, let me get a pencil in here.
I got GF, I mean G2, intelligence.
Chief of staff, later chief of staff, the same.
So you became the chief legal officer then?
No, no, no.
That was the first job I had.
Okay.
Then I was,
G2 is intelligence and legal officer.
Okay.
And then I was made chief of staff.
I had all these other people under me.
Okay, okay.
How many men did you have under you as chief of staff?
Well, we had 50,000 people.
We had all the people in the San Diego area.
You ought to put San Diego area.
Yeah, you have that.
I have.
All right.
And what rank were you at this time?
I was still a lieutenant colonel.
Okay, a lieutenant colonel.
Anyhow, we had Camp Pendleton, we had Camp Elliott, we had Camp Gillespie, we had Camp Matthews, we had all these places under this same outfit.
It was commanded by a general, General Vogel.
See, who had me?
